body:
Hi @hassaanmahmood 

It depends on the data, but if your data is significantly different, you probably couldn't use the test_vol as a reliable test. If the data is very similar then you can, and I would recommend you affinely register the data to our atlas to start indeed. 

If you'd like to use our pre-trained models, you should carry out the pre-processing described in the paper. If you'd like to avoid doing this and would like to try your own preprocessing, then I would recommend you train your own model.

Thanks a lot @adalca
Sorry for asking too basic question. in this image my image is white , and your atlas overlay is in red color. 
how can I get them in similar view? after getting them in same space I will do affine registration.

may be there is problem with uploading the  image. Actually sagittal plane of my data is corresponding to coronal of your atlas. when I overlaid them in Mango software to view. What can I do solve this please.
thanks

It sounds like your data is in a different orientation. 

- I would recommend you get used to visualizing data in python, look into `matplotlib.pyplot.imshow`, and in our tools look at [`neuron.plot.slices`](https://github.com/adalca/neuron/blob/master/neuron/plot.py) .

- if you want to rotate the orientation so that it is similar to ours, i recommend looking into `numpy.transpose`, which enables permuting dimensions

Thanks a lot. 
your atlas size is (160, 192, 224)
my subject size is (144, 192, 256)
Am I right in my steps to make my image like yours one.
1- orientation 
2- resize/resample
3- affine registration
How can I achieve these steps.
Also please , as you said in the paper "All scans were resampled to a 256x256x256
grid with 1mm isotropic voxels. .... and
crop the resulting images to 160 x 192 x 224."
does crop mean resampling?

seems right

for orientation i would use `numpy.transpose`
for affine registration you can use something like [ANTs registration](http://stnava.github.io/ANTs/). if you register to our provided atlas, you don't have to crop. See [*Notes on Data*](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph#notes-on-data) for more details.

Thanks for your comments. I have data without skull stripped. I am using free surfer, but getting inadequate stripping, some portion of eyes included in the mask and also some part of boundaries of brain has been removed by free surfer. 
1-should I use any other tool for skull striping?  Or I have to go through different parameters for watershed. 
2- it is taking more than 12 hours per volume even if I use  -autorecon1 option.
3- Also can you please guide me how to resize the volume.

1. What sort of data do you have? There are many skull strippers out there, and it depends on your data. If some of the images were well skull stripped with FreeSurfer, you could simpley train your own UNet to segment the brain

2. Yes, if you'd like to reproduce our exact pipeline *and* evaluate the data on segmentations, FreeSurfer takes a long time. Note that this is not completely necessary for VM. What you need for voxelmorph is affine registration and intensity normalization. Skull stripping is suegul, but 100% necessary.

3. I'm not sure I understand the question. if you are using your own atlas (or doing subject-to-subject) registraiton, your image sizes are fine. If you would like to resize an image, you can look at `scipy.ndimage.interplation.zoom` for python or `resize` in `https://github.com/adalca/neuron/blob/master/neuron/utils.py` for tensorflow.

I will be using ADNI dataset.
Its a naive question, Just want to confirm from your experience. As far I learned from the issues,
 1- Freesurfer is not mandatory for training data pre-processing. 

 2- if yes, we can do it in any software by doing 
     a-intensity normalization  
     b- skull stripping
     c- affine registration to your atlas

3- if we use freesurfer , Can training data be prepared by only running Autorecon1 option in recon-all Or we have to run complete recon-all pipeline for training data preprocessing?

4- If we use other software for pre-processing of training data and freesurfer for Test data preparation( because we want segmentations), Is it good idea to do that? I only want segmentation to compare my results, for that I need to do it with freesurfer. 

5- If using different software for training and test data is ok, will difference in Intensity normalization and skull stripping create problem in performance. if yes how can we reduce it.

Can you please tell me where I am wrong in my understanding.
Looking forward for your guidance. 
thanks
Hassan

1. True
2. True -- in fact, I don't think all of that is always necessary, and I would say we're probably days away from releasing our own steps for 2a and 2c with voxelmorph.
3. I think this should be fine
4. Well I'm not sure of the resulting behaviour to be honest. It's best to have train/val/test all with the same processing -- so I think 5. is moot, then

I tried with a sample MRI . run complete recon-all . and used brain.mgz and aseg.mgz as my test_vol and test_seg respectively. 
But I am getting very low dice score, I am sure doing something fishy here. Can you please have a look . 
What I am missing here please. I also attached the pdf version of my notebook.
[notebook.pdf](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/files/3506477/notebook.pdf)

`

# py imports
import os
import sys
import glob
from argparse import ArgumentParser

# third party
import tensorflow as tf
import numpy as np
import keras
from keras.backend.tensorflow_backend import set_session
import nibabel as nib
import scipy.io as sio
from scipy.interpolate import interpn
sys.path.append('../ext/medipy-lib')
import medipy
from medipy.metrics import dice
import datagenerators

# project
import networks
sys.path.append('../ext/neuron')
import neuron.layers as nrn_layers
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

Using TensorFlow backend.

moving= '/home/hassan/Work/test5/mri/brain.mgz'  # from freesurfer recon-all
test_seg='/home/hassan/Work/test5/mri/aseg.mgz' # from freesurfer recon-all
model_file= '/home/hassan/Work/voxelmorph/models/cvpr2018_vm2_cc.h5'

labels = sio.loadmat('../data/labels.mat')['labels'][0]
atlas = np.load('../data/atlas_norm.npz')
atlas_vol = atlas['vol']
atlas_seg = atlas['seg']
atlas_vol = np.reshape(atlas_vol, (1,)+atlas_vol.shape+(1,))

mov_nii = nib.load(moving)  # from freesurfer recon-all
mov = mov_nii.get_data()
mov = mov/255                #normalizing
print(mov.shape)
mov = mov[48:-48,31:-33,3:-29]
print(mov.shape)
mov=mov[np.newaxis,..., np.newaxis]
plt.imshow(mov[0,100, :, :,0])
mov.shape
np.amax(mov)

(256, 256, 256)
(160, 192, 224)

0.7372549019607844

custom_layers = {'SpatialTransformer':nrn_layers.SpatialTransformer,
                 'VecInt':nrn_layers.VecInt,
                 'Sample':networks.Sample,
                 'Rescale':networks.RescaleDouble,
                 'Resize':networks.ResizeDouble,
                 'Negate':networks.Negate}

net = keras.models.load_model(model_file, custom_objects=custom_layers)

/home/hassan/anaconda3/envs/tf3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/keras/models.py:282: UserWarning: No training configuration found in save file: the model was *not* compiled. Compile it manually.
  warnings.warn('No training configuration found in save file: '

pred = net.predict([mov, atlas_vol])

X_seg = nib.load(test_seg).get_data()   # from freesurfer recon-all
X_seg = X_seg[48:-48,31:-33,3:-29]
X_seg = X_seg[np.newaxis, ..., np.newaxis]
plt.imshow(X_seg[0,100, :, :,0])
np.amax(X_seg)

255

vol_size=(160,192,224)
nn_trf_model = networks.nn_trf(vol_size, indexing='ij')
warp_seg = nn_trf_model.predict([X_seg, pred[1]])[0,...,0]
vals, _ = dice(warp_seg, atlas_seg, labels=labels, nargout=2)#
print(np.mean(vals), np.std(vals))

0.3480438429552605 0.24704607653702573

 

`

- you should try using norm.mgz since that's what we used, just to compare directly.
- can you visualize `atlas_seg` and `X_seg` and `warp_seg` in subplots? or using `neuron.plot.slices` ?

Thanks a lot for your response. Would there be any wrong with my preprocessing in this notebook. in freesurfer , I ran complete recon-all. we are using sample from adni.

This time I tried with norm.mgz of the same subject.
Using neuron.plot.slices, there are plots at the end of the attached document.
[notebook_6.pdf](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/files/3509698/notebook_6.pdf)

@hassaanmahmood almost there, can you add colorbars and the moving *image*?

I think the low Dice might just be an issue of different labels in the different files, somehow...

Sorry, I guess I meant the `moved` image.
So have something like:

```
moving_img | fixed_img | moved_img
moving_seg | fixed_seg | moved_seg
```
with the top cmaps being grayscale
and the bottom all being the same (e.g. inferno)

Basically, I'm not sure I understand what's going on with the labels -- they don't seem bad at all after warp, so I'm trying to understand if there's just simply an issue with some inconsistent labels being used.

Thanks for your time. 
1-  Just confirming my understanding. there is difference of sharpness in getting moved image from `warp_mov = nn_trf_model.predict([mov, pred[1]])[0,...,0]` 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20740538/63317732-8fd8fc00-c346-11e9-8341-ecd63c294b84.png)

and getting it using directly  `[moved, warp] = net.predict([mov, atlas_vol])` . 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20740538/63317722-88195780-c346-11e9-8b3f-a192fcdea5a4.png)
Is this difference meant to be there?

2- here I am getting moved_img by `[moved, warp] = net.predict([mov, atlas_vol]) `  
`moving_img| fixed_img | moved_img `
                 `moving_seg | fixed_seg | moved_seg`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20740538/63317858-f6f6b080-c346-11e9-9a8a-46b20778fa92.png)

3- So Sorry for my previous comment.. This data is sample from IXI Dataset . But I am getting similar result on ADNI too. Preprocessing is done by complete recon-all . 
4- When I overlayed images in MRIcron...... my moving brain is translated and not aligned with `atlas_norm`. where as from matplotlib we can not see this difference,
gray is my input sample
red is norm.mgz from fress surfer
blue is your atlas_norm.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20740538/63319978-ab480500-c34e-11e9-814f-f9176d1bd700.png)

thanks for your time and looking into this problem.

Hi @hassaanmahmood ,
1. Yes, you would lose sharpness with a moved image, since the warp uses linear interpolation (you could also use NN interpolation, but I don't recommend that for warping images.

2. I think this is an issue with extracting the right labels -- it seems that your warped segmentations is using the freesurfer label IDs and your fixed is in [0, 31]. Can you make sure that for your warped segmentation, you re-mapped the labels according to `labels.mat`? 

4. Looks like a header issue -- how did you save the `nii` of the warped image and which `nii` are you using for the atlas?
